Posts.Content: KLee wrote: I am finally having surgery tomorrow to put a stent on my kidney to help it drain. I have had problems for years with both kidneys, and they are barely functioning. It has gotten to the point where my right kidney is so bad that they may have to leave a tube coming out of my kidney that will drain into a urine bag. I am hoping this is not the case, but they won't know until they get in there. I am pretty nervous about this,because I don't want to feel any pain. I think the worst part will be when they give me the local anesthesia, that has to go pretty deep in to the kidney. This is a very sensitive area for me, as I have tumors all over my chest wall, very close to this area. I am just a wreck thinking about this. Normally speaking, I am by no means a wimp, and have a high tolerance for pain, but I can't help remembering when I had my surgery to remove my old portacath, and have a new one replaced only 2 months ago. The nurse was supposed to give me some IV sedation, and she did not...so, needless to say, I felt the whole thing, and it was pretty uncomfortable. I am also concerned that this surgery site will easily become infected, as I am currently undergoing chemo treatments with Taxotere. I wish I did not have to deal with this because I am dealing with enough problems right now. Of course, I do not have a choice-if I don't do this, I risk kidney failure. The doctors can't really even tell me what has caused all this, but the urologist thinks it may be to long term chemotherapy, not to mention all the enormous amount of drugs I have been on in the past 17 years. Any words of advice, or has anyone else been thru this with kidney stents?? Dx 11/1999, 1cm, Stage IV, 2/20 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Has anyone here had surgery to place stents in kidneys? KLee barbe1958

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 04:57AM KLee wrote: Thank you for your responses. I must relay my experience from friday...I went in to the one day surgery section at my local hospital, as scheduled early fri. morning. Needless to say, I was not happy to be there. I looked up on their surgery schedule board, noticed my name, with the surgery, and the Dr. who would be doing the surgery. To my astonishment, it was not my Urologist, but the surgeon I had 2 months previous from Interventional Radiology, that had removed/inserted my porta-cath. When I had that surgery done 2 months ago, it was not the greatest experience. I was totally awake, with nothing for pain, except the local injection. I was advised, and made sure that I would have something for pain thru my IV (Fentanyl). This is my 3rd placement of a porta-cath, so, nothing new. When the wheeled me into the radiology room, the nurse was on her cell phone, on a personal phone call with her husband-she had found out she received a job promotion, and was very excited. In her excitement, she forgot to administer the fentanyl thru my IV. I was fine for the first half of the procedure, but the second half, it started to get quite uncomfortable. The Dr. knew this, as I was squirming all over the table, didn't say anything to the nurse...until I finally did. She had given me some fentanyl, and I swear, 2 min. later, the surgery was done, I had felt the whole thing. Needless to say, I was not too happy. I should not have to deal with pain from any surgery's or tests, because I deal with alot of different pain on a day to day basis. I knew going in that I would have a local injection, very deep into the kidney, which I was very paranoid about. Mostly because I have a large scar with major scar tissue and cancer tumors on the outside of my chest wall, all very close to the kidny area, and it is very sensitive and I often get pain there. I was told I would get "mild IV sedation", and this just did not sit right with me. I couldn't help thinking like "yeah right, just like last time". I kinda started mildly freaking out, and told the nurses there that I was having 2nd thoughts, and probably would not be having that surgery done that day, until I had more answers about the surgery and the bad condition of my kidneys, and I wanted to make sure that I would not feel any pain.I have heard that this can be painful, even one of the nurses told me so, and was wondering why this was not scheduled for general anesthesia. I don't think my husband was too thrilled, nor were the nurses, because I put up a stink ( I didn't get loud or obnoxious), and had thrown off all their schedules... I say, tough!! I've always had great instincts and good common sense (for the most part), especially when it comes to my health, I've been doing this for 17 years! The crazy thing is, they wanted to try and put the stent in my right kidney, but with most liklihood I would end up with a neph. tube and urine bag - and then 2 weeks later, the same thing for my left kidney. This does not make much sense to me, I'm just wondering, does any of this make any sense to you, and do you think I was out of hand, by not wanting to be in pain with this surgery? I am still in the same dilemma, as time goes on, my kidneys are worse, ( the right one is functioning at about 20%-and the left at about 50%) and I must get this done ASAP. I did make another appt. with my Urologist to see what the heck is going on.
Posts.Title: Has anyone here had surgery to place stents in kidneys? KLee barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 08:39AM KLee wrote: Mine were in the 700's about 10 years ago. I have managed to get them down around 100 (which is good for me) over the years, with hormonal tx. and Xeloda. Of course now, they are in the 800's, which are high. I think these are for my CA 15-3 markers though. I think this signals that the cancer is active, I know my cancer is now. Tumor markers, along with scans have always been pretty reliable for my cancer. The markers can certainly go back down, hopefully and most likely with some type of treatment. And No, this does not signal that the end is near. Good Luck Bonnie, and let us know what's going on.
Posts.Title: Tumor markers WAY up BonnieVA tami444

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2009 04:41PM KLee wrote: I have been on Xeloda for 4 years now. It has been working well for me. Besides exhaustion, I seem to tolerate it well, and it has removed all the bone pain I had. I would say at least try this!
Posts.Title: if bald now,will hair etc grow back on xeloda?? nolagirl KLee

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 09:24AM KLee wrote: I have been a "metster" for 10 years now. I have been on both sides of the fence. When I was first diagnosed, I was 34 years old, with Stage 2. Of course back then, there was no internet. When I was diagnosed with my re-occurrence with mets, I initially started going to a women's breast cancer support group at my local hospital. I went at least a half dozen times, but found myself unable to go anymore. At the time, I had decided to treat my mets with hormonal therapy drugs, as oppossed to the lethal chemo drugs-well, not many women there thought what I was doing was smart, and they let me know it, so much so, that I had to stop going. Well, ten years later, I am still here...wonder if they would like to talk with me now??
Posts.Title: Advice for metsters konakat RobinWendy

Posts.Content: May 19, 2009 09:23PM KLee wrote: Heidi, I am also bone mets, skull to knees. My husband and I made the mistake of doing most things for our 3 kids while they were growing up. Our youngest is still at home (18), but still doesn't like to pitch in. Some days I can physically accomplish alot, others, I am in bed. My husband has his own business (construction), and works alot of hours. Many days he comes home and has to cook and clean. Would be nice to have some kind of help, even once or twice a week. Any suggestions anyone?
Posts.Title: POLL: What type of help do you get around the house? mason204 KLee

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2009 08:33AM KLee wrote: I'm not sure about 2 months, but I was only on Tamoxifen for 4 months. I'm not sure if it helped, but what I do know is it put me into menopause (at 41 years old), almost immediately, therefore I did not have to undergo an oopherectomy.
Posts.Title: Onco Confused...Help! Worried_Hubby jmar19

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 11:09AM KLee wrote: Thanks so much for your responses. It does sound like this will be tough, but hopefully doable. I was also wondering, has anyone had to do the steroid (forgot the name of it), previous to the Taxotere. I've heard that some actually get some extra energy after the steroid. That would be great for me. I guess it is suppossed to help with the swelling that the Taxotere can give you.The hardest thing sounds like it will be the taste buds, and how everything will taste repulsive. I know that by drinking lots of water, that helps to flush out the chemo., but I so hope that I will be able to find something that I can eat, anything... Oh, and any vitamins, minerals or herbs that may be beneficial, or that you should stay away from when on Tax.??

Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2009 11:09AM KLee wrote: 34 with stage 2 41 with stage 4 (with mets to most bones and lung) I will be turning 52, in a few more weeks! At 34, I had 3 young children : 9, 6 and 2 years old. It was a very scary time in my life! I now have 4 grandchildren! I know how scary it is for Mom's that have very young children - I never thought I would be alive to see them grow up...
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: KLee wrote: I've been doing fairly well, all things considered up until about a week ago. I am trying to find something positive that I can hold on to, to help me keep pushing. I have been stage IV for the past 10 years, but have managed to do fairly well until the last 6 months, when this damn cancer has gotten aggressive, and now many days it is pretty overwhelming for me. It seems to be one medical problem/issue after the next. I started weekly Taxotere tx. in early Oct., so now have about 3 months into this. I'm not sure if the Taxotere is working, but I seem to have more patience than my husband or my Oncologist. My Onco. has always used tumor markers, along with scans, etc. to see how I'm doing. For me, the tumor markers have always been pretty reliable, and over the past 10 years have been all over the board. My CA 15-3 have pretty much never been low or normal. In Nov., they were 892, after about 6 weeks of tx.- just a few weeks ago, they had dropped some to 832. I feel this is a step in the right direction, of course we had all expected better results. Because I am so ill right now, my Onco. is only doing the Taxotere at 35%, and has expressed his wanting to add 10% more and also adding Cytoxan. I am not so "gung ho" on this idea as he is, and with good reason. In a 7 day week, I am pretty much in bed all day for 5 days, have no energy, but on rare occassions, I can get up and out for a few hours a week. I have managed to keep my weight stable, (at 93 lbs.) for the past few months, and still have not had my kidney surgery yet. This past week I have been getting very short of breath, and know that my lung is filling with fluid. In the past month, I started spotting and then bleeding, and have not had any (female) bleeding in the past 10 years, which means that something is obviously going on in that dept. as well. I am trying to deal with all of this, along with feeling so alone, because I am. In the past 10 years, I have been on Tamoxifen, Aredia/Zometa, Femara, Faslodex, Xeloda, and all have seemed to help me. They didn't work overnight, but I have definetly had success. Should I try and have even more patience than I have with the Taxotere, or should I start looking into other options? I don't know how much more of this I can do...I am house bound, and I should say snowbound, and I manage to get out of the house once a week, for my chemo appts.-big whoop, which my husband takes me to. I usually spend the winter down in Florida with my son & his family, but at this point, am not healthy enough yet to do so. I just lay in bed most of the day and watch the tube...it's driving me nuts, can't get housework done, I feel useless. When my dh gets home from work, he just ignores me, and won't help me out. I've always been very independent, highly motivated, and have always taken care of everyone else, so this new lifestyle is very difficult and troubling for me. Any ideas anyone, on how not to go freakin crazy? Dx 11/1999, 1cm, Stage IV, 2/20 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Am getting pretty depressed... KLee Fidelia

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2010 11:22AM KLee wrote: Fidelia, what you said about your DH, sounds very similiar to my husband. I think my husband has just tried to shut down through most of this lately, because it is the only coping mechanism he feels he can use right now. An update from last week. I was doing pretty bad last week and could not breath well at all. I pretty much knew that my pleura was filling up with fluid fast. Well, last friday, I went into the lung Dr.'s office, and she drained 1 liter of fluid off my lung in about 10 min. time. It really wasn't painful, and was so totally different than what some other dr>'s put me through 10 years ago, which was a nightmare - and the more I think about it now, the more it pisses me off. Anyways, it was a big relief. I am breathing better now, but still have alot of coughing and shortness of breath. Of course this could fill right back up with fluid again. My onco. thinks that now maybe we should change my chemo from taxotere to taxol. Has anyone here had any sucess with taxol? This friday I finally get to have my kidney surgery, not that I've ever been looking forward to it. In meeting with my Urologist again in the past month, he told me that my right kidney is pretty much gone, and that now I need to concentrate on my left kidney, because that has not been functioning well either. I also found out that they will not be placing a stent, but instead will be putting in a neph tube, with it hanging out of my back (about 1 inch lower than my lung thoracentesis)connected to my LOVELY urine bag that will now be accompanying me wherever I may go. What a joy...just can't wait!
Posts.Title: Am getting pretty depressed... KLee Fidelia

Posts.Content: KLee wrote: Hi all, I will be starting Taxotere in the next 2 weeks, and am wondering how you have tolerated this chemo. I hear that it is a really rough one. I have been on Xeloda for the past 4 years, but it is not really working now. I tolerated the Xeloda quite well, and years ago was on CAF, and also tolerated that fairly well. I just really am stressing out about the hair loss (that goes without saying), but also possible bone pain, not to mention all the other possible side effects. I can barely even get out of bed most days now, and I'm not even on any chemo at the moment...yikes! I will be going in once a week for the Taxotere for 3 weeks on, as oppossed to one infusion evry 3 weeks, so I am hoping this may help. I have lost alot of weight, and am hoping my little 98lb. body can tolerate all this. Dx 11/1999, 1cm, Stage IV, 2/20 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I am to start Taxotere, any info or advice? KLee jadams1264

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 11:59AM KLee wrote: Thanks Linda and abbyglp, I guess thats what I'm afraid of is the Neulasta for the WBC's, thats what I hear gives you the bone pain. I already have Oxycodone on hand if I need it, so I will not hesitate to use it as needed. I'm just really worried about the appetite thing. As it is, I have to pretty much force food down right now, I'm just hoping that the Taxotere is not going to make this problem worse. I will be getting my tx weekly on thursdays, which I'm assuming will make the weekends difficult. My husband will be home on the weekends to help me, but then I probably won't be doing much of anything either. Do either of you get nausea or vomiting? Yes, generally speaking, losing our hair is a small price to pay for extended life, however, it gets harder the older you get, how many times we have to lose our hair, and the less time we have to live. I've been doing this stage IV for 10 years now! Best of luck to both of you!
Posts.Title: I am to start Taxotere, any info or advice? KLee jadams1264

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 01:06PM KLee wrote: That does seem very high. I have been on Xeloda for 4 years now, and have always taken 1500mg. (3 - 500mg. pills) in the morning, and another 1500mg at night. I had been doing 2 weeks on and one week off, until just recently, (have lost alot of weight), so now I am on the same dosage, but doing one week on and one week off.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2009 08:15AM KLee wrote: I am stage 4 and from Syracuse, about a 2 hour drive from Albany.
Posts.Title: Is there anyone from upstate new york area? ead Jelson

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2010 07:51AM KLee wrote: I finally had my kidney surgery done this past friday. I had been putting this off for about 6 months, and have been dealing with other medical issues as well. Last month I found out that we would not even bother doing anything with the right kidney, as that is barely functioning (10%). I had been putting this off mainly out of fear, the fear of pain...now I can see why. When I was in on friday, I almost walked out (again)asking myself why would I put myself through kidney pain, when I don't have any now, and also why would I want to walk around with a urine bag attached to me? I had to do alot of convincing just to get them to make sure I was out of it during the procedure, which they did. My Onco. was even wanting to give me a chemo tx on friday, after I had already been thru this - I told him no thanks. When I got home friday, the pain was unbearable, even when on continuos pain meds. It has gotten somewhat better in the last few days, but am still on plenty of pain meds, and hoping the pain will lessen in time, but I'm not sure. Every time I urinate now-its painful. Not to mention, now I have to go in every 6 weeks to have this tube changed, although they have told me it will be nothing like it was on friday. Its been a rough couple of weeks for me, as the friday before last, I had to have my lung drained of fluid, and am hoping it will not return. Its hard tho, because I have been very short of breath for awhile. Anyways...now my Onco. wants to change my chemo from Taxotere to Taxol, this week, and then next week add Cytoxin to the mix. I am somewhat unsure of this. I asked him about Abraxane, as I've heard it may be easier to tolerate than Taxol. One of my problems is the hair loss, which I know is trivial in the whole picture, but it seems to be my only saving grace right now as far as not looking totally SICK. I have had continuos hair loss with Taxotere, it comes out in handfuls all day long, and it drives me nuts. However, I still do have some of my hair, and i"d like to keep it that way. I just don't want to end up totally bald, with no chance of ever being able to grow my hair back again. We are not even sure if the Taxotere was even working either. Sometimes lately, I can't help thinking that nothing is going to work for me, at least not like we had hoped. My Onco. told me that insurance does not like to pay for Abraxane, when they can use Taxol/Taxotere instead - does anyone know about this. HUGS to all of you.
Posts.Title: Am getting pretty depressed... KLee Fidelia

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 04:30PM KLee wrote: I'm not ready to give up yet on the taxotere, although it is not shrinking the tumors/lymph nodes as we had hoped. My largest problem at the moment is the breathing. I've had a small effusion on my left lung for some time now, but I'm sure it has increased dramatically in the past week. I had a chest x-ray last thurs., and not sure what it says. All I know is I may have to go to the ER soon for oxygen, and I'm sure to drain this effusion. I am scared to death of this, as I have been thru this nightmare 10 years ago, and I have to say it was torture...the worst thing i have been thru in my 17 years of BC. I know one of the S.E. of Taxo. is pleural effusion. Other than this, being tired alot, and having no appetite, I am still tolerating the Taxo. fairly well. I usually get scans every 6 months, or more as needed. Even though I usually manage about 5 crappy days out of 7, I still live for the 1 or 2 decent days a week I have, and will continue to think that even that is good and still worth it, because I know it is. Quality of life is always important, and I have done a pretty good job with this for quite awhile. Funny thing is my Onco. told my DH a few moths ago that as far as "quality of life" goes, he said we are not there yet. I love my Onco., and we know each other well after 9 years, but I had to tell him that anyone who is stage IV is always thinking about and trying to find and keep the ways of having the best quality of life. I had to make him understand that it is not just about when you are on your deathbed, it is about EVERY DAY. My DH helps out sometimes, but is usually so exhausted himself every day its difficult for him. We've been together for 30 years, and he has been thru this long journey with me pretty much every step of the way...until lately. He says he feels helpless, and doesn't know what to do. Sounds like a sorry ass excuse to me, because HE is tired-what does he think I am? He's always been a workaholic, and has been able to somewhat hide away from my stage IV for the past 10 years. Now, he has been acting like gee, how come your cancer got this bad so fast?? He is always miserable (he used to be a happy person) and makes me feel aweful. He's told me that he feels sorry for me, and he feels pity, I say its much more like GUILT, for all the years he was never around because he was working. He was always my best friend, we don't even have that anymore. I guess all the tough years have more than worn out their welcome. You all had some great responses, and I really appreciate them. HUGS to all!
Posts.Title: Am getting pretty depressed... KLee Fidelia

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 06:05AM KLee wrote: Hi Worried Hubby: The second Dr.'s opinion sounds much more plausible than the first. I agree with Elaine, I would press on with him. It is possible for your wife to have Ovarian cancer, as it is similiar to Breast ca.. I have had mets to my bones for the past 10 years, and I can say that sometimes you can be totally asymptomatic, with no bone pain. I would keep up on the tumor markers, and CT, MRI or pet scans, and bone scans maybe every 6 months or more for now. How long ago was your wife doing chemo.? I agree that more clarity needs to come from the pathology reports. Good luck to you & your wife. Hang in there and hopefully you will receive better answers soon. It's nice that you are so involved, and an excellant advocate for your wife!
Posts.Title: Onco Confused...Help! Worried_Hubby jmar19
